text: Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.
draft. backlog. bitter, slick, piney hops. Very good. Oily and bitter finish.
Bottle ,thanks to shrubber85, dark orange with frothy foam, lots of lace, bready fruit nose, fruity rich apricot and marmalade flavor , good finish
Bottle pour. Bomber. Pours a very cloudy amber. Aroma is citrus zest. Flavor is bitter grapefruit. Overall, solid beer, not as exceptional as Zombie Dust and other heavily hopped 3 Floyds beers.

Orange clear pour with a single finger head. Aroma is sweet, full of caramel, grain & some earth-like notes. Huge mouth. Taste is full of grain with a more bitter than usual finish for the style. Very clean, floral finish. Super easy drinking for being such high gravity. Lace present.
Fad: Orange uklar øl med et lille skumhoved. Duft af humle, tydelig three floyds men smagen er domineret af lagergær der clasher en lille smule med humlen. Lidt mærkelig øl uden den store balance.
bottle. golden with one finger head. rather substantial pilsner malt base. big noble hops. just a bit boozy. pretty nice beer.
Draught at Pazzos. Hoppy and sticky with some big sweetness overall. Decent orange pour. Fairly good overall.

Tap at Milkeller Bangkok. Poured a clear medium amber with a thin broken white head and some broken lace. The aroma is malt, weak citrus hop. The flavour is moderate bitter with a zesty citrus yeast palate and a short, slightly spicy bitter finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Aroma is fruit/berries, citrus/citrus peel, malts and slightly perfumed. The flavor is fruit/berries, malts, citrus and slight heat/alcohol/tartness in the finish.

Sampled at GABF 2014 with Andrew, Mel and company. Pours a light golden body with white lacing. Aroma is fresh hop and crisp, clean malt. Mouthfeel is light with carbonation and notes of fresh hop, grass, citrus, and clean malt. Very good clean, hoppy pilsner.

I know Ive had this on tap before, but this is my first time having it out of the 22oz bottle. Slightly thick/hazy orange-tan. Foamy off-white head. At first the lager tones escaped me, the crisp clean hop tones stole the show, but at the same time they are smoother, more rounded than youd expect from the style, no real big noble hop bite. This drinks more like a Strong Pale Lager than an Imperial Pils. And it drinks quite nice. Very well balanced. Highly enjoyable beer, sessionable. Excellent.

Draft. A hazy amber beer with a lazing beer a beige head. The aroma has notes of malt,, caramel, and spicy hops. The flavor is swweet with notes of malt, alcohol, and caramel, leading to a dry finish. A bit raw.
22oz bottle pours a yellow amber color with a bit of head. Darker in color than the usual pils color. Very malty and medium hop level that overpowers a little.

On tap at Sugar Maple in Milwaukee. Its dark in here, but this beer appears to be a nice amber color. Very sweet aroma. Lots and lots of malt. Good hop bite, but mostly sweet tasting from the grains. Interesting and good.

September 5, 2014. On tap at Mikkeller Bar Stockholm. Pours hazy orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty, plum, floral, grass and citrus. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter, malty, floral and light sulphuric. Finish is light sweet and bitter, some fruity notes. Light/medium bodied.
Aroma of bitter hops, taste is bitter, hoppy, lots of grass, very easy drinker, I like for the style.

From tap. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is toasted malty and light breadish/malty. Grassy, toasted malty and flat. Bitter and light caramelish. Cardboardish and flat malty, grassy and straw.

Hazy amber/orange color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of floral hops, yeast, & grain/hay; Flavor of slight sweet malt, floral hops, caramel, grain, and citrus; Finish is dry & slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Nice enough.
Clear orange with tons of carbonation and a decent, fizzy head. Strong yeast smell, grass, wet leaves on the ground, earthy. Tangy Euro-style Pils flavor. Pretty dry; papery crispness. A good brew.
A good pilsner, which is great because I find most pilsners rather boring. This has a nice hop profile with some good alcohol burn in the end. Easy to drink.

Draught at Mikkeller Stockholm. 
Round and quite big body but yet a lager freshness. Nice fruity hop aroma.

On tap at Mikkeller Bar Stockholm. Pours cloudy golden amber with a low white head. Aromas of rye bread, citrus, orange rinds, musk, hay. Taste is rye bread, orange rinds, slight peach, grass. Mouthfeel is somewhat lively with medium carbonation.

draft sampler poured a yellow color with white head. the nice aroma of a pils with a little touch of hops (sarcasm). has a nice pine aroma. the flavor is traditional pils which I do really like and a nice hop flavor from start to finish. not the best pils but definitely not the worst.
Draught at MikkellerBar. Clear golden - white head. Toasted. Fruity. Light bitterness. Some sweetness. Piney. Tea. Light caramel. A bit like an old dusty pale ale.

Draught @ Mikkeller Bar. Pours deep golden with a creamy offwhite head that doesnt leave much trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is slightly malty and slightly fruity biscuits, butterscotch, persimmon, moist grass and lemon zest. Taste is sweet, tiny bitter, tiny fruity and herbal with sweet dark bread, butterscotch, moist grass, lemon balm, persimmon and lemon zest. Mouthfeel is round, tiny sticky sweet, tiny boozy and medium bodied. Finish is sweet, bitter, tiny fruity and tiny herbal with butterscotch, moist grass, lemon balm and lemon zest. Ok...

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Clear orange colored with a small off-white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel and hops with notes of tea, candies and pine needles.
Sweet and fruity flavor of caramel, hops and candies with notes of pine needles.
Hoppy finish.
I cannot believe this is a 7.0 abv. Smooth, smooth, smooth. Not a lot going on, but satisfactory hops and flavor.

Pours a slightly hazy pale golden yellow with two fingers of fluffy white head. Aroma is slightly floral and sweet. Flavor is slightly sweet malt. Biscuit. Floral. Slight bubblegum also. Medium bodied. Nice beer.

Got this as an extra from a DLD trade. Here we go:

A: pours a light golden lager with a single finger of white suddy foam which falls to a veritable sheet of the same with ascending collared grace. Excellent to brilliant clarity.

S: Smells of classic grainy pilsner. Catch includes a bit of metallic scents in there. Wishing for a bit more crispy final hop notes. 

T: Tastes like a pilsner with corn added. Not impressed. The grain bill is evident, and simple. 

M: Medium feel with moderate carb. Slightly dry on the finish.

O: This is an unimpressive beer for FFF. Imperial Pilsners can be so much more: hops and malts can take on beautiful and compex nuances. Too bad they were unable to make this happen.

Serving type: bottle

05-30-2011
Pale golden body with a starch white head. The aroma is Very much noble hops and biscuits. Flavor is moderate biscuit malt with lots of noble hops. Medium body and crisp.
Light straw color huge fluffy cloudy white head. Grainy sweet aroma light citrus. Avg palate. Slightly bitter finish a big pils taste pretty good not going to buy it.

Poured a golden color from the bottle with aromas of grass, malt, and a touch of wheat. Flavors are the same, with a boozy aftertaste, a decent beer overall, just not the first one I would grab out of my fridge.
Orange pour from 22 oz bottle at long room. White fluffy head. Fresh wheat and grassy flavor. Great for the style

Three floyds does a pilsner right. Nicely bitter but has a little skunky flavor. Pours a light cloudy yellow in color. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
HisBoyElroy on the split. Late hop flavors linger afterwards. Overall not bad.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2014 Bottle: thanks, Josh! Clear golden & yellow body, foamy white head with nice lacing all over the glass. Aroma is bready malt, lightly sweet with some musty & ashy hops, finishing touch of citrus spritz & lemon zest. Taste is mild, pilsner malts, bread & crackers with a very timid sweetness. Mid-palate dusty & spent hops with mild bitterness and some leafiness. Finish of light lemon & orange zest, dry and a little yeasty.

Bottle. The pour is light with thin head. The aroma is that of a true pilsner. The taste is full of malt and holds true to style.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
22 ounce bottle. Thanks Alan! Pours a light gold with a nice white head. Aroma of florals, malt, and yeast. Taste is florals, malt, lemon, yeast, and grain. Very nice!!
22oz bomber from the pub pours a straw yellow. Malt and wheat aroma. Taste is the same with a bit of hop finish

Every FFFs is an adventure not to be passed on. This power pilsner amplifies all the characteristics of a good pilsner. Normally subtle in many ways this pilsner is loud and wants to be noticed. Pour from a 22 with a classic golden hue and white head.
UPDATED: OCT 15, 2013 Not much going on here at all. I cant say anything about it. It isnt bad. Its just very run of the mill.
Bottle shared by a friend. Pours clear gold with a medium white head. Aroma of malt and noble hops. Malty flavor with some fruit and light herbal accents before a crisp noble hop finish.
Bottle from FFF. Poured pale yellow with good head. Light resinous aroma with some grain. Medium carbonation with balanced hop forward pils taste. Very Floydian.

On tap at Argus Bar Grille in Madison, WI. for their GToM pre-party. Enjoyed by shaker in the Underground, displaying a clear golden color, with a modest layer of white, frothy head foam, and spots & streaks of lacing. The aroma was typical but expressive pils, lager, and noble nose. The flavor was amped hops & malt, with some malty sweetness. Best of the Imperial Pils tried so far. Well rounded and very drinkable, but isnt the style kind of a conflict in terms?

Bottle. Hazy gold with a thin white head. Aroma is lagery yeast and pilsner malt. Taste is the same and a touch of citrus. Palate is full for a pilsner with a great dry finish and heavy carb bite. Very refreshing and flavorful. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance:medium light yellow with a dense but fluffy white head that left significant swathes of soapy lace.  Aroma: 	big dose of floral and grassy hops over a barely detectable bed of crackery pilsner malt.  Taste: bright citrus tang and big floral hops up front, then a good hit of slightly sweet toasted white bread. Finish: crisp but not clean (in a good way), as the lingering hops dry the palate nicely. Notes: This was, simply, great. The palate was spot on perfect, and the hoppy character was borderline insubordinate. Also, the cover art looked like a cross between Heironymous Bosch and Warhammer 40,000.
Bottle shared at natifest. Pours a pale yellow with no head. Aroma is floral and fruity. Tastes fruity, sweet, and a touch floral. Overall, one of the better imperial pilsners Ive had to date.
bomber thanks to AndyReynolds at Natifest - pours straw with white head with nice lacing. nose is straw and light cat urine. Flavor adds citrus hops. light and refreshing.

5/11/2011: Three Floyds Evil Power Imperial Pilsner... Aroma: Doughy malt, herbal Noble hops, yeasty. Appearance: Hazy yellow color; frothy off-white crown; low level of visible carbonation. Flavor: Pils malt paired with a light citrusy hoppiness with a splash of pine; mild to moderate bitterness. Palate: Medium-light body; smooth and very easy going down. Overall: This isnt anything over the top, but this is a nice, easy to drink, and enjoyable brew thats easy to drink and quite sessionable; not overly heavy like other "Imperial" Pilsners.
1 pint 6 fl. oz. bottle shared by alexdad06. Thanks Brad! Rating #96 for this beer.

Pours a clear gold color. This white head that lasts the entire beer. Aroma is grain and sweet. My bottle seems to have an off flavor I cant place followed by a tart finish. Grain flavor and some sweetness.

Pours a clear golden with a lot of carbonation and a huge, white head.  Aroma is full of dish soap, oranges, grains, and floral hops.  Taste is clean and hoppy, and has a light body with a grainy aftertaste.  Im a fan of pilsners, and this doesnt even hold up to some of the cheaper imports.

Bomber pours a hazy golden-yellow with two-finger white head and some lacing.  Aroma is full of floral hops, honey, and some grain/grass.  Body is medium with slight carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.  Taste is mostly bitter, but well-balanced.  It lacks the signature citrus hop bitterness found in so many other FFF beers.  An excellent Imperial Pilsener, even if its not one of my favorites from FFF.

Bomber. Pours a pale straw color, medium white head. Nose is old school hops, malty cerealness. Mouth is medium, lemon zest, cereal, malt, the basic Pilsner. ABout what Id expected and not something I wouldve gone out of my way for but it was on the shelf at Binnys and 3Fs is one of my favorite brewers so I figured what the hell. Better than Miller and the like, but still overpriced.

Bought on DLD day. 
Pours a bright yellow with white head.
Smells of sweet bread & a hint of hops.
Slight hop taste upfront which ends in a definite pilsner bread yeast.
Not a pils fan even on a good day but this is doable most likely to their hops used.
Overall this is a nice pils in both style & taste.  3F did it well.

Yellow-gold with good, creamy, frothy, white head, modest legs / Floral nose of grain, honey, cream / Medium to full body, some sweetness, excellent balance with  fine bitter finish / Flavors of grain, resin, honey, wildflower / Really nice.  Big but not overbearing with exceptional balance.

Bomber. Pours a clear golden/yellow with a huge, frothy white head that dissipates very slowly. Not much lacing. Nose is very welcoming. Sweet and very hoppy. Citrus hops to be specific. Grapefruit and a bit of lemon zest make this one delicious. Mouth is not early as good as the nose. Taste is very breadlike with a slight hint of spice and floral hops. An interesting grass like tast is present. Medium bodied.

Im a raving metalhead btu Lair of The Minotaur just blows and I love thrash metal, they are talentless. Just listen to some Celtic Frost or Sarcofago. Slightly hazed yellow pour. Bready malt smell with light candied citrus/mostly herbal hops. Flavor has some initial smoke which is odd. It turns into an overly sweet pils. Probably the best "imperial pilsener" I have had forma  US brewer but still not all there.

Let me start off by saying that i dont like pilsners, but i love three floyds and will try anything they make.  This is an odd bird.  They made a pilsner, but in typical 3 floyds fashion, they filled it with an insane amount of fruity hops.  The result is a beer that starts off like dreadnaught but ends miller lite.  Has the black tea and sawdust finish of a pilsner.

Bottle: pours cloudy pale straw, bright white head. Hay, mild buttery notes, bread, grains on the nose. Biscuit, grassy malts, nice sweetness and then bitterness for drying effect on the finish. Bigger bodied Pilsner that grew on me. Better than Jinx Proof.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Good German hop flavor similar to the jinx proof but more bitter and bigger malt body. Flavors linger nicely.  Thought this one was pretty well done. Defintly has an intensity and the end if the palate that pilsner a dont have but the flavor pattern is very similar. A amped up pilsner just as the name dictates.

Draft:
Pours clear gold, small white head.
Nice hoppy bitter aroma and flavor.
ABV is very well hidden.
Not bad, not bad at all.

Draft. Golden. Small white head. Earthy hoppy, grass, grain. Very much a middle of the road" beer. Not offensive in any way but not a super standout. Good balance. Very good for the style but somewhat normal by FFF standards.

On tap at DLD 2013. Clear golden color. Thin white head. Good retention, good lace. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Good moderately dry finish. Nice bready taste, light pepper. Good lightly spicy hop. Impressive for the ABV, how drinkable this is. Doesnt taste "imperial". Good moderate bitter taste, no hint of alcohol. More dry finish. Awesome imperial pils. Doesnt taste much stronger than a normal pils. Pretty stealthy.
Draft to half-pint at DLD. Looks good for a style; a transparent orangish-gold with white head. Smells semi-sweet, doughy, and bitter. Tastes like it smells with a nice, smooth finish. Good beer.
Backlogged rating:  Pours a light gold with a sizeable white head.  Nose has some cracker characteristics to compliment the lemongrass notes.  Medium bodied...flavor follows suit.

22 oz. bottle.   Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a large fluffy white head.  The aroma is floral, herbal, doughy malt, and grass.  The flavor is grassy and herbal hops, sweet doughy malts, some sweet caramel malt notes. Medium bodied.  This was definitely better on draft at DLD.
Bottle. Pours apricot gold with white head. Nose/taste of alcohol soaked peaches, orange peel, malt, pepper and citrus bread. Medium body.
Light yellow pour. White head. Crisp aroma. Pale malt, hops, light yeast. Flavor is nice, pils malt, yeast, a hint of unripe fruit. Good.

Served on tap at Marias Package Goods and Community Bar during Chicago Craft Beer Week.

A: Pours a nice hazy orange with a decent .5 finger, off-white head.

S: Immediately big malts hit the nose with a great yeasty back drop. Some sweetness is floating around, almost like a ripened fruit.

T: Slight sweet watermelon for a brief second follow by the intense malt roast in the middle. Bitter hops at the end, but not as pronounced other imperial pilsners.

M: Light/medium bodied with nice carbonation. Leaves a malty film over the mouth after each sip which tones down the bitterness.

O: Better than other Pilsners, but still just sort of an average beer. Nothing popped or stood out for me on this one.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-22-2011

22 oz bomber from DLD 2011. Time to open this, I guess. Pours a big puffy head over a darker gold lager color. Takes a while for the head to finally settle to a short layer. I am not getting much in the way of nose, probably a consequence of letting it age for a year. well, then again, there is a welcome whiff of alcohol after a few more sniffs. Sipping it does give the nice impression of a high-powered malt liquor, without the headache inducing fusels (Heloooo Big Hurt). A true gargleblaster to give my sore throat a wakeup call, with not just alcohol but fizz. I would have thought this would have the standard Noble hops, and a hint of perfume suggests that, but theres also a citrus bender that suggests C&Cs. Its a nice way to celebrate ALMOST finishing my Oracle Database class and getting back to looking for a job.

Pours a hazy light orange with a fizzy white head.  The aroma is sweet, bread, yeasty, floral, and earthy.  The taste is sweet light malts with medium bitterness.  I wish it were a bit hoppier, but not bad.

65cl, no mention of ABV, as Evil Power Imperial Pilsner, new exclusive American brew Anno 2011, thx to Secret Santa!, complex brew, floral/sweet and slightly malty/fruity, very balanced, hazy, rocky head, good brew, yet expensive!

22 oz bomber from a trade with The Alum. Poured a slight chill hazed dark rusty orange body with an average sized foamy white head. Aroma is sweet with notes of green grapes, raisins some honey and bread. Fuller bodied with average to slightly strong carbonation and a quick fading aftertaste. Flavor of old wet bread with some honey and grapes, basically its sweet and grainy overall. Interesting beer but Im still not sold on this style.

Bomber from Secret Santa (alexsdad06) - thanks for this. Ive loved Impy Pils ever since Sam Adams brought theirs out. Pours hazy orange tinged gold with a creamy near-white head. Aroma is bready and citrusy/fruity. Unusual. Med + body. Wow. Its hoppy. It is hoppy.* Now the hop seems rather Saaz. It has something of a barley wine aspect. It just gets better and better. Gets lush. Yum.
*in a relative sense. Darn hoppy for a lager!

Bottle , Hazy light orange color with a fluffy white head. Aroma was a bit yeasty with hints of honey and light citrus. Flavor was very much the same as the aroma, sweet and a tad yeasty. Overall a good showing here.CHEERS!

Bottle shared by BenC...thanks Ben! - Pours hazy golden amber with a thin off-white head. Honey cornbread on the nose with some yeast and light herbal hoppiness. Very fruity taste, with lots of yeastiness, pale malt, and an almost sugary note. Feel like the hops are blanketed by the other flavors, and theres very little crispness. Grassy hops on the finish, and the whole thing is pretty mouth-filling. Just not my style--I want this thing toned down, crisped-out, and a little more easy-drinking.

Pour is a clear light gold bordering on yellow color with a small white head. Nose is a bit malty with some light fruit notes as well. Taste is rather sweet with a little bit of a citric hop bitterness in the backend.
Bottle.  Orange/peach malt and citrus peel aroma.  Golden yellow color with large head.  Sweet orange malt and moderately bitter orange peel flavor.   Nicely blended.   Nice - easy to drink.

22 oz bottle shared with sherm1016.....from lake beer fridge.....an older beer from the fridge...may have lost an edge on the crispness factor but still a tasty pilsner (which usually isnt two words used together...)....hope they do it again...

22oz bottle, purchase at DLD 2011. Pours a clear, amber color with a big white head and some lacing. Aroma is malty, cereal, bread, a little spicy hops. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is bitter, spicy hops, malty, cereal, with a nice bitter hop finish. Not FFFs best, but a tasty pilsner.

A- Pours a darker yellow, almost orange with a white beady head.

S- Malty and bready. 

T- Sweet malty taste. Slight bit of bitterness on the backend

M- light mouthfeel. Medium carbonation .

O- not a bad beer, nice lacing but probably wont seek this one out again

Bomber courtesy of Forgetfu (thanks Bill) poured a clear tarnished gold with a lasting white head. Aromas of graininess, bread, earthiness and spicy hops. Palate was medium bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread, yeast,earthiness and spicy hops with a crisp lingering earthy finish.

Im not a big pilsner fan, but this is a very good version of one.  Usual pilsner aroma, color and taste.  If Im in the mood for a pilsner (not often) Pilsner Urquell is the usual choice.  This is better than that - also probably considerably pricier.

Pours pale bright yellow with a foamy white head. Smell: grass, light earthy note, lemon and hint of hops but all in all light on the nose. Huge malt and effervescent on the tongue, slight lemon note,  floral notes but the alcohol kind of over powers the slight nuances that come in a pilsner. Not a bad beer by any means just not a favorite.

Brown bottle, 22 ounces, purchased at Three Floyds, savoured on July 24 2011; eye: copper, clear, no effervescence, tiny ring of kaki head; nose: malt, light herbaceous hops, light fruity, mineral; mouth: malt, light hops, caramel, mineral, malty finale with light fruit presence, medium body, average carbonation, lightly bitter and sweet, lightly velvety texture; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS 

Bouteille brune, 22 onces, achetée chez Three Floyds, savourée le 24 juillet 2011; il : cuivrée, claire, pas deffervescence, petit anneau de mousse kaki; nez : malt, léger houblon herbacée, léger fruité, minéral; bouche : malt, léger houblon, caramel, minéral, finale maltée avec légère présence fruitée, corps moyen, carbonatation moyenne, légèrement amère et sucrée, texture légèrement veloutée; en résumé : bien bon

22oz bottle from NobleSquirrel, thanks 
Appearance: Pours slightly cloudy golden with a big white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Fruity, dusty caramel and spices  
Taste: Slick mouthfeel of sweet caramel, dusty, spices with light bitter lemon rinds in the finish 
A nice, easy drinking Pilsner

A lightly hazed golden amber imperial pils with a thin creamy light moka head. In aroma, a mineral whiff of fresh air, grainy malt, fresh and smooth. In mouth, a smooth crisp malt with German hops, light alcohol, quite nice. Bottle shared with GRM and ProbstK. July 24 2011.  Merci Sylvain!

Bomber from StFun  thanks J!  Pours highly carbonated gold with a half finger white head.  The nose is pilz spice, citrus, malt.  The taste is spice, lemon zest, grassy hops, light grapefruit and malt.  Medium prickly mouthfeel.  Tasty pilz  thanks again J!

22oz bottle thanks to Marc. Rating #56. Bright orange/gold color with a dirty white head. Malty, doughy aroma with a hint of orange. Sweet with a kind of an oily mouthfeel, a little boozy and a slight bitterness. (1831)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: On tap at DLD 11. This was a very likable, well balanced, and strong lager with some added standard 3Fs hops that are hard to beat. Bright orange in color, and a thicker clumpy, standard white head. The aroma is of pils malt, grassy spices, and then florals, melon, and citrus. Bitter qualities here are very pleasant and nicely integrated throughout. Flavor notes of cereal grains, grassy spice, pils malt, melon fruit, and mixed tangy citrus. The finish is nicely balanced with grains, citrus, and grass. One of the better impy pils Ive had. The hop profile probably has a lot to do with that.

Bomber shared by GRM (merci!), served cold in a tulip glass. Sweet label.  My second 3 Fs. 24JL11.
App.:  Clear deep golden with a small light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Minerals, metallic, lightly fruity, grassy hops, very Pils, biscuit, a little peppery, nice...not evil.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, fairly light effervescence, smooth enough.
  
Flav.:  Strong herbal hops, sweet fruity malts, peppery, green, a bit soapy and woodsy; off-dry with a long fruity malt + some leafy hop finish.

Evil is good!

The was courtesy of Strykzone who continues to send me great beers. From the 22 oz bottle with the killer label this poured an orange to light amber with a very robust white head and sticky lacing. Body is medium and mouthfeel very smooth and easy to handle. Flavor is malty with some hop bitterness.. and light citrus. Bitter finish. Well done Imp. Pils.

Bomber from boss Josh - thanks, your holiness! Absolutely killer label, it goes without saying, and I love the emergent series (someone get me the Amon Amarth, please). Fairly cloudy deep yellow pour, riotous head and fairly prominent lacing. Nose is not especially sharp, but its got a ripeness to it that seems fitting for the style and the band. Initially its a bit too sweet from the malts but it soon turns the cheek to show you the raucous bitters. Its never been a style that Ive warmed to overmuch, but yeah I guess it works. But at times it seems like all attitude, kinda like LOTM.

On tap at the brewpub.

Aroma: Light cereal, pinneaple and honey. Well done, but quite subtle.

Appearance: Copper blond with nice head.

Flavors: Honeyed cereals, caramel malts, light hops.

Palate: Liquorous and full.

Overall: As good as an Imperial pils can be.

Date: July 11, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: bvery, Burnsville, MN Appearance: Orange with a tint of yellow and slight amount of head Aroma: Citrus fruity, maybe some peach in there Flavor: Consistent with aroma, slight carbonation and slight bitter finish Other: Great for its style, but obviously not a powerhouse offering from 3 floyds.

Bottle. Mostly orange, somewhat yellow pour with a nice foamy white head when poured aggressively. Sweet biscuit nose with a touch of peach. Semi-carbonated feel, with again biscuit and light fruit tones on taste. Nice brew.

Pours a deep clear copper color with a full white fluffy head.  Smells of sweet crystal malts, citrus hops, hay, and honey.  Light and lively on the mouth with a slight bitter hop finish and a bit of grain.  A bit watery at times.

Bottle. Pour is a clean gold with a nice white head/good lacing. Aroma is peaches, fruity hops, bread. Flavor is bready, citrus, soapy. Palate is clean, slick, lightly bitter. Definitely good and to style but its not a particularly exciting style to begin with.

A: The pour on this beer is a bright orange-amber color with a finger or so of white head.

S: Not a great nose, but decent.  Sweet bready and cracker malts with a bit of apple juice and some floral hops.  A little bit of yeast and caramel sweetness.

T: A more well put together flavor.  Plenty of malt giving the beer a nice bread and biscuit flavor.  There are lots of floral malts and a hint of citrus peel.  A light bitterness on the back end rounds it out.

M: Medium in body with a medium carbonation.  Could have used a little bit more effervescence, though.

O: Imperial pilsners can often been too sweet, but this had a nice balance to it.

651mL thanks to tastybeer. The pour is a hazy dark peach color with a healthy, large, buttermilk head. Bulky lace. Nice retention. Nose is sour peach. Taste is doughy, sharply bitter, a bit suddy, mildly tart, noticeable alcohol. Finishes a bit watery with cardboard. Palate feels slick and buttery but sourness cuts out an unpleasantness. Not bad. But I dont think any brewery could sell me on the imperial pils idea.
A really good pils. Light pour with a sweet and a little skunky aroma. Flavor is light and this beer goes down really easy. A nice contrast to the hoppy offerings.

Growler from the brewery brought by my good friend raveskdr. Poured an orange color with a fluffy thick white head. Aroma is orange citrus, notes of hops, almost biscuit malts. Flavor was citrus, almost grapefruit. Alcohol is a bit noticeable, but it is still very tasty.

Bottle thanks to Sarah! Pours a clear gold with a white head that dissipated slowly to the edges. Aroma had a good amount of sweet grains and light floral notes. A bit of cookie as well. Flavor starts with sweet grains and becomes a bit sweeter with a cookie note. A bit sweet and muddled for me.

Bottle from bauermj.  Thanks!  Dark gold, nice fluffy white head on top.  Spotty lacing sticking to the sides of the glass.  The aroma shows grains and biscuity pils malt with some grass and flowers in there as well.  The flavor is plenty bready sweet and slightly sticky but it also has some crisp hops to counter that fairly well.  Some lighter citrus fruit hangs around, melon comes to mind, with notes of herbs and grass.  A little alcohol kicks in towards the finish as it also tries to dry out.  Solid beer.  Not too Imperial and cloying, although I definitely wouldnt have wanted it any stronger.
Tasted 5/18/11. 22oz bomber. Full bodied with a bitter body. Nice cola effervescence. Sticky, cloying malty flavors. Herbal and fruity. Decently melded. Good.

had on tap at three floyds, but now looking at the bottle art I wish I got a bottle (not sure if they had it avalible with I was there).  came to the take with a clear orange color with a very white head.  The smell is of citrus and yeast.  Taste is of lemons and fruit and you get the 7.2 on the back end.  This beer finishes intereting the alcohol is masked on the front but than is present for the finish of the beer.

aroma is lightly corny, wet cereal grains, backgroudn white lightning.  grass of noble hops burn below.  appearance is well polished, lightly darkened honey yellow, wonderful lasting head perched atop.  lightly vegetative, good balance of classy/grassy noble hops and cereal malts.  few off putting aspects of character are pleasant in that they are associated with the style.  some alcohol esters at play even at 8.2%.

22 oz bottle.  Clear golden orange with a whipped white head.  Nose is lemon pith, dough and orange peel.  Syrupy body with a tang and a tingle.  Taste is melon, apple, peach and bitter lemon.  Finishes a bit like a whiskey with the heat emerging.
Bottle purchased at DLD 2011. Poured hazy blonde with small head. Kind of harsh at first and it got better as it warmed up. Very good.
pretty good pils. nice flavourful fruity hops throughout. nice bitterness as well. fairly heavy as well.
Bottle purchased at DLD 11. The beer tasted very strong and bitter, it was very harsh to drink at first but yet it was good to drink after a few, tasty stuff. interesting style

22 oz. bottle picked up at FFF brewpub.  A cloudy and light brown beer with a smallish golden head that never leaves.  A nose of fruit and floral hops.  Flavor is quite robust saying this pilsner is, indeed, an imperial.  Plenty of hops that are bitter, floral and piney, and yeast.  A strong malt backbone but the hops reign.  Some nice fruit flavors add interesting notes.  This is generally sour.  Pretty nice but this is a challenging style.

Bottle, courtesy of TheAlum. Thanks a lot! Clear golden yellow appearance with a white head. Sweet, lightly floral, mild hoppy, pale lager nose. Smooth, moderately hoppy, fairly strong pale malty flavor. Crisp finish.
Bomber.  Nice beer here.  Certainly floyds as it isnt your typical imperial pils.  Was wanting a bit more crispness in the hop profile as the aroma alluded to.  Drink like its bigger than 7.2%.

22oz bottle pours a lightly hazy, deep gold with a frothy, white head.  Sweet, honey nose, sugary, a little grassy, a overly sweet malt.  Flavor is lightly grassy, sugary, malty, honey.  Full bodied, sweet finish.
Pretty smooth texture. A medium body and had a small amount of hops. Warm but pale color with a medium size head.

Bottle shared by Dosbeerigos. Hazy light orange color with a fluffy white head. Aroma was a tad yeasty with hints of honey and light citrus. Flavor was very much the same as the aroma, sweet and a tad yeasty. Overall a good showing here.

22 oz bottle from beernbourbon. Clear golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma of malt, bread dough and a touch of alcohol. Flavor is rich and malty with just a light alcohol warming and some light hop bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation and a smooth, soft mouth feel. Nice beer for the style, very clean and smooth with a kick. Thanks Vince.

This does not resemble a Pilsner in anything but color. I sometimes wonder if some American brewers have even tried a damn Pilsner. Sure, this is supposedly, a strong version thereof so they can reasonably have some differences but this is quite simply nothing at all like a Pilsner. So why call it that? Hell, I guess its a beer word people have heard, maybe it just saves time to call things something they arent... Its not a bad beer though. Its pale golden beer w/ a nice white head. Nose is quite fruity w/ a slightly sulfur-like bread yeast character. Honestly, Id be as likely to guess its a Belgian yeast as a lager by which I mean to say this is squarely in American ale territory as far as the yeast character. Its surprisingly fruity for  its claimed style and really much closer to an IPA w/ its soapy bitterness and citrus elements. The texture though is a high point, very smooth w/ crisp carbonation. This a decent brew just nothing close to resembling its claimed style.

Pours a slightly hazy gold with a lush lager-type head.  Aroma is dough with woody and herbal hops.  Taste is like a slightly syrupy pils with a lingering woody finish and a hint of spicy yeast.  Mouthfeel is incredibly creamy.  Glad to see the Floyds extending their supremacy to the realm of the lager!!!

On tap at the brewpub during Dark Lord Day 2011. Pours a mostly clear, golden-orange colored body with a finger-width, frothy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is grassy lemons, sweeter pale and bready malts, and some florals. Flavor is similar. Smooth, medium sweet bready pale malts with a hint of caramel. Lots of floral fruits and lemony citrus-grass balanced nicely. Finishes moderately bitter and dry with lots of floral citruses and grass, but a solid balance with the malts. Not cloyingly sweet like a lot of imperial pils. Ends very pleasant with a lengthy aftertaste. Medium-light, smooth, fairly crisp body and a moderate carbonation. Overall, a nicely constructed imperial pils. Lots of hops, but well balanced with a solid, never too sweet malt backing. Good beer.
At Darklord.  Pours gold with a white head.  Light aroma, sweet malt.  Herbal hops in the flavor, caramel malt.  Decent brew.

Golden pour with modest white head.  Nose is sweet malt and herbal/earthy hops.  Flavor is malt-forward...sweet, bread dough, caramel.  Hops are largely muted... herbal and earthy.    A smooth and creamy texture. Just OK.

Tasted on 5/19/11 from a 650mL bomber bottle purchased at Three Floyds during Dark Lord Day.  Pours hazy orange with a thick fizzy white head that slowly recedes to a very thin but even collar of lace.  The nose is lightly nutty with hay, bread, grass, dough, and a hint of green hops.  The flavor is more hoppy than anything else with some grass and bitter earthy hops along with some nuttiness, hay, bread, and dough.  The body is medium and somewhat oily with average carbonation and a long lightly bitter grassy hops finish.  There is some alcohol heat on this beer, but it is in no way out of balance.  As a matter of fact, this is one of the most balanced "strong Pilsner" I have had.

22 oz. bomber from the brewery, purchased on Dark Lord Day. Pours a bright gold color with a small white head. Aroma of corn, straw, pale malts, light grassy hops- the corn also comes out in the form of corn flakes. Flavor of corny grains, booze, sweet malts, sugar, and grass. Medium-bodied with medium-high carbonation and a harsh, bitter mouthfeel. Maybe its the style but this wasnt for me. Probably my least favorite FFF beer to date.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured a clear copper color with an average frothy white head that was mostly lasting and produced good lacing. Moderate hops and small malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid brew and very good for style.

Bottle; Pour is light golden with a nice white head with modest retention ; very light spotty lacing in this tulip. This brew has an excellent floral hop nose, lacking some of the grainy funk that you might expect from the style. Florals, a light grainy character is offset by the hop profile, which is heavier than is typical for the style, but what would you expect from FFF. I enjoyed this one for its drinkability.

Thanks to Armin for bringing the bomber!  Poured clear honeyed golden with a short, dense white head.  The aroma picked up strong grainy and grassy notes with a cereal malt backing.. not over the top with hops, but there was definitely a lot in there.. balance was solid.  The flavor found grainy notes and honey at the core, with earthy and grassy bitterness around.. finished more assertive with earlier character amplified by alcohol.. this was a solid example of the style (which isnt a very good one).
Pours amber with short head.  Light malt and hop notes drive a blast of hops that carry on through the finish.  Grains are present and near the finale so is the ABV.
On tap at DLD11.  Orange yellow with white head. Malts citrus hops somewhat grainy in that european import sort of way. Some noble hops and lots of grain.  6/3/7/3/14

On tap at DLD. Pours hazy yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is very grassy and full of light wheat and citrus notes. Flavor has some hot alcohol in it with grains, grass, earth, and spices in the finish/body. Very carbonated. Medium bodied.

tap at dld. pours golden with white head, a floral grassy doughy malt aroma. fl is grassy hop notes, sweet doughy malts, with a stale faded hop finish with sweet caramel malt notes. finishes too sweet for my taste.

Picked this bottle up at Dark Lord Day. After excitement, it fails to live up to expectations. Served in a Russian River pilsner glass.

Pour yields a mostly-clear golden-colored brew with a thin (for the style) white head and not much lacing. Some spots as it goes down, after a few swirls. The nose carries a bit of light grain and a very slight touch of floral hops. A bit bready. The flavor is all too bready without a real ho component to back it up. It seems like its a bit stale, which I would expect to be the case had I not just picked it up at the brewery. Body is far too thick with a strong bready component. Hops are tertiary; Im not sure whats secondary. Adequate carbonation but I cant get past the excessive body and lack of bitterness or anything resembling crispness. Not a fan, not a fan at all.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-03-2011

On tap at Dark Lord Day, enjoyed while listening to some metal band that had 2 flying V guitars. Pours an orange color with a nice head and some lace. The aroma is some sweet maltiness, a little raw grain, plenty of citrus hoppiness, and a bit of fresh hay. The flavor is very fruity and spicy, hoppy and decently bitter, with a malt character that is both very bright but also a tad sweet.  
Seemed a little more Mai-Bock-y than Imperial Pils-y, good beer either way though.

A: Very clear, light amber pour with nearly no head.  

S: Citrus hops and lemon peel dominate the nose while bready pils malts are in the background.  A little bit of hot alcohol as well.

T: Delicious spicy hops are up front with a nice grainy pils backbone.  Nothing overly complex, as you should expect with a beer of this nature.  Youd never guess this is 7.2% by taste.  This is a wonderfully crafted beer.

M:  This has more body than some other impy pils Ive had before (DFH My Antonia comes to mind) but it serves it well.  Medium carbonation doesnt scrub away flavor too quickly and leaves a great taste in your mouth.

O: A fantastic beer with a small cast of flavors that hold hands and get along great together.  Kudos to FFF for another delicious beer.

On tap at DLD 2011
Appearance: Pours an amber orange with a thin white ring of head.

Aroma: Fragrant German hops.

Taste: Spicy hops and pale malt. Nothing corny that I could tell. Fairly clean with well hidden alcohol.

Mouthfeel: Highly carbonated, which made the hops all the more spicy on my tongue.

Overall: Im glad I tried it, it wasnt something Id seek out or buy for $10.00 a bomber, but solid and well executed.

DLD11 on tap.  Pours straw yellow with white head, aroma has bready, grassy and some slight fruity notes.  Taste is mixed with notes of grassy and earthy hops, some sweet bread and fruit notes, finishing slightly dry and bitter.  Not sure why this was an imperial pils, but I much prefer this to most as imperial pils has become IPA...this is much more towards an amped up pilsener.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2013 Have to rerate 2013s offering.  Much better, lots of citrus.  Pretty damn good in comparison.  Not much skunk.  Lots of fresh hops.  Impressed.

2011 - 2.5. Draft at the brewpub.  Aroma is hoppy and a little skunky.  I amnot a pilsner fan.  So, this rating may not be too fair.  I will say it is one of the better I have tried.
tap at DLD.   pours a light orange.  notes of breads, herbs, a touch of green raisin.  some light citrusy, earthy hops.  touch of bubblegum.  good.

Draft at DLD. Pours a reasonably clear and slightly dark gold with a creamy white head. The nose is really nice with pure pils malt aroma coming through witha delicate sweetness and some herbal hop notes. A touch of alcohol peeks through as well. On taste, I love that it is not overly sweet at all. Great pilsner character between the soft bittering and doughy malts and a round fruity melanoidin component. Not exactly what I had expected, but this is really solid stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2011 pours a dark clear orange, dark copper in the middle, a decent bright white head... really nice nose with lemon, floral hops, and a bit of alcohol... more alcohol comes through on the taste but its a really nice imperial pils... would have this again

Draft on tap at DLD (Munster, IN). Pours a nice deep dark orange golden pour, with a healthy bright white head, laces well, vibrant soapy froth and ok haziness. Aromas are vibrant florals and lemons with pale malts, bread, and biscuits. Some lemon, pine, and florals round out. Initial is medium bodied, gentle bready and biscuits, moving into some lemon and florals, grass, some ABV sweet. A bit hoppy, moving into sweetness which cant be held back. Soapy, touches of more lemon, with a light rind. Finish is lingering sweetness, ok hops. Nice, a little sweet. An ok bigger beer. It went a little mediocre after the aroma.

Bottle from DLD2011.  Orangish yellow pour with medium white head.  Aroma has a lot of strong citrus and leafy hops.  There is some doughy malt in the nose as well, along with a bit of pale malt and crisp lager yeast.  Flavor has a lot of strong citrus hops, mostly orange and lemon.  Fairly clean flavor, crisp and dry.  Certainly masks the alcohol content.  Doughy malt presence with some serial grained.  Its Medium bodied,  finishes on a leafy hop note.  Pretty nice beer.

Enjoyed on tap at Dark Lord Day (3 Floyds) in Munster, IN.  This is the first beer I had, which was at 10 AM on a Saturday which is somewhat of a rarity for me.  At any rate, super happy this was brewed with the intense metal band Lair of the Minotaur!   Appearance a very bright, vibrant orange with a thin white head.  Aroma not really too much, lager yeast and some soft malts.  Taste is pretty good, has that nice pilsner malt/crispness but definitely packs a punch.  Also a sweetness in the backing.  Imperial pilsners arent typically on my radar but its not bad.
